panels.description: The cluster status
panels.title: Status

panels.description: The number of nodes configured in the cluster.
panels.title: # Nodes

panels.description:
The number of CPU Cores actively used in the cluster.

Note that CPU Cores that belongs to unreachable nodes, or nodes that are not in normal mode, will not be counted
panels.title: # Cores

panels.description: The number of tables
panels.title: # Tables

targets.expr: sum(rate(scylla_transport_requests_served{instance=~"[[node]]",cluster="$cluster", dc=~"$dc", shard=~"[[shard]]"}[$__rate_interval])) + (sum(rate(scylla_thrift_served{instance=~"[[node]]",cluster="$cluster", dc=~"$dc", shard=~"[[shard]]"}[$__rate_interval])) or on() vector(0))

panels.description: Average Write Latency
panels.title: Avg Write

panels.description: P99 write Latency
panels.title: P99 Write

panels.description: Average Read Latency
panels.title: Avg Read

panels.description: P99 read Latency
panels.title: P99

panels.description: The percentage of the time during which Scylla utilized the CPU. Note that because Scylla does busy polling for some time before going idle, CPU utilization as seen by the operating system may be much higher. Your system is not yet CPU-bottlenecked until this metric is high.
panels.title: Load

panels.description:
The rate of timeouts (read and write).

Timeouts are an indication of an overloaded system

targets.expr: (sum(rate(scylla_storage_proxy_coordinator_write_timeouts{instance=~"[[node]]",cluster="$cluster", dc=~"$dc", shard=~"[[shard]]|$^"}[$__rate_interval])) or on() vector(0)) + (sum(rate(scylla_storage_proxy_coordinator_read_timeouts{instance=~"[[node]]",cluster="$cluster", dc=~"$dc", shard=~"[[shard]]|$^"}[$__rate_interval])) or on() vector(0))

panels.title: Timeouts

panels.description:
This graph shows how IO queue consumption is distributed between io-groups and streams.

scylla_io_queue_consumption

targets.expr: $func(rate(scylla_io_queue_consumption{iogroup=~"$iogroup", class=~"$classes", instance=~"[[node]]",cluster="$cluster", dc=~"$dc"}[$__rate_interval])) by (instance, iogroup, stream)

panels.title: I/O Group consumption by instance

panels.description:
This graph shows the ratio of dispatch rate to completion rate. It is expected to be 1.0, growing larger on reactor stalls or disk problems.

scylla_io_queue_flow_ratio
panels.title: I/O Group Queue flow ratio

panels.description: Total time spent in the queue

targets.expr: $topbottom([[filter_limit]], max(rate(scylla_io_queue_total_delay_sec{class="$classes", instance=~"[[node]]",cluster="$cluster", dc=~"$dc", shard=~"[[shard]]"}[$__rate_interval])/rate(scylla_io_queue_total_operations{class="$classes", instance=~"[[node]]",cluster="$cluster", dc=~"$dc", shard=~"[[shard]]"}[$__rate_interval])) by ([[by]]) or on() max(scylla_io_queue_delay{class="$classes", instance=~"[[node]]",cluster="$cluster", dc=~"$dc", shard=~"[[shard]]"} ) by ([[by]]))

panels.title: $classes I/O Queue delay by [[by]]

panels.description: Number of requests in the queue
panels.title: $classes Queue length by [[by]]

panels.description:
The queue bandwidth rate in bytes 

scylla_io_queue_total_bytes
panels.title: $classes I/O Queue bandwidth by [[by]]

panels.description:
The rate of io queue operation

sscylla_io_queue_total_operations
panels.title: $classes I/O Queue IOPS by [[by]]

panels.description: Total time spent in disk

targets.expr: $topbottom([[filter_limit]], max(rate(scylla_io_queue_total_exec_sec{class="$classes", instance=~"[[node]]",cluster="$cluster", dc=~"$dc", shard=~"[[shard]]"}[$__rate_interval])/rate(scylla_io_queue_total_operations{class="$classes", instance=~"[[node]]",cluster="$cluster", dc=~"$dc", shard=~"[[shard]]"}[$__rate_interval])) by ([[by]]) or on() max(scylla_io_queue_delay{class="$classes", instance=~"[[node]]",cluster="$cluster", dc=~"$dc", shard=~"[[shard]]"} ) by ([[by]]))

panels.title: Disk $classes I/O Queue delay by [[by]]

panels.description: Number of requests in the disk
panels.title: DISK $classes Queue length by [[by]]

panels.description:
The time the class waited for being dispatched with non-empty software queue.

Large IO delays coupled with small starvation time denotes that scheduler is doing its job properly, and it's upper layer that overflows disk capacity.

Large IO delays coupled with large starvation time denotes that there might be some problem on the scheduler level that it cannot deliver IO requests from that class into disk in timely manner or the disk is slow and cannot afford timely dispatching.
panels.title: DISK $classes starvation time by [[by]]

panels.content: Information by Task Group

panels.description: Scylla employs an event-loop like reactor that alternates between the execution of different groups of tasks periodically. This graph shows how much time was spent in $sg group
panels.title: Time used by [[by]] - $sg

panels.description: Scylla employs an event-loop like reactor that alternates between the execution of different groups of tasks periodically. The maximum amount of time during which a task group can run is called the "task quota". Some task groups may disrespect that and run for longer. This may cause latency issues
panels.title: Time spent in task quota violations by [[by]] - $sg

panels.description:
Scylla employs an event-loop like reactor that alternates between the execution of different groups of tasks periodically. The maximum amount of time during which a task group can run is called the "task quota". Some task groups may disrespect that and run for longer.

 This graph shows the amount of time the group was waiting to get CPU time.
panels.title: Starvation time by [[by]] - $sg

panels.description: Shares assigned to the $sg. Shares determine how Scylla reactor distributes the task quotas between groups (Higher share gets more quotas)
panels.title: Scheduler shares [[by]] - $sg

panels.description: Number of Read requests that failed due to an 'unavailable' error
panels.title: Local Reads Error by [[by]]

panels.description: Number of write requests that failed due to an 'unavailable' error
panels.title: Local Write Error by [[by]]

panels.description: Number of Stalls per seconds.
panels.title: Stall per seconds by [[by]]

panels.description: Number of Read requests that failed due to an 'unavailable' error
panels.title: Reads Unavailable Error by [[by]]

panels.description: Number of write requests that failed on a local Node
panels.title: Write Unavailable Error by [[by]]

panels.description: Number of write requests that failed on a local Node
panels.title: Range Unavailable Error by [[by]]

panels.description: Number of AIO Errors
panels.title: AIO Error by [[by]]

panels.description: Total number of abandoned failed futures, futures destroyed while still containing an exception.
panels.title: Ignored Future By [[by]]

panels.description:
Number of C++ exceptions thrown.

 An exception by itself does not indicate a problem
panels.title: C++ Exceptions [[by]]

panels.description: Holds the size of disk space in bytes reserved for data so far. A too high value indicates that we have some bottleneck in the writing to sstables path
panels.title: $func reserved disk space by [[by]]

panels.description: Holds the size of disk space in bytes used for data so far. A too high value indicates that we have some bottleneck in the writing to sstables path
panels.title: $func used disk space by [[by]]

panels.description: Counts a number of times the flush() method was called for a file
panels.title: $func flush by [[by]]

panels.description: Holds the current number of commit log segments
panels.title: $func Segments by [[by]]

panels.description: Counts a number of times a flush limit was exceeded. A non-zero value indicates that there are too many pending flush operations (see pending_flushes) and some of them will be blocked till the total amount of pending flush operations drops below 5.
panels.title: $func flush limit exceeded by [[by]]

panels.description: Holds the number of currently pending allocations. A non-zero value indicates that we have a bottleneck in the disk write flow.
panels.title: $func Pending allocations by [[by]]

panels.description: Counts a number of requests blocked due to memory pressure. A non-zero value indicates that the commitlog memory quota is not enough to serve the required amount of requests.
panels.title: $func Pending flush by [[by]]

panels.description: Holds the current number of unused segments. A non-zero value indicates that the disk write path became temporary slow.
panels.title: $func Unused segments by [[by]]

panels.description: Holds the number of not closed segments that still have some free space. This value should not get too high.
panels.title: $func Allocating segments by [[by]]

panels.description:

If you do need a panel that can be saved, create a new dashboard, or edit the panel inside the json file
